intro: Elymus innovatus f. laxatus, commonly known as the looseleaf wild rye, is a grass species characterized by its slender, loosely arranged inflorescence. It is native to regions of Europe and Asia, often found in disturbed soils and open habitats. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, with narrow, grass-like leaves and spikelets that are loosely clustered. Its botanical features make it adaptable to various environmental conditions, contributing to its ecological significance. It is valued in ecological restoration projects due to its resilience and ability to stabilize soil.
